values.description:
Going from a machine centric approach to a constellation based one. Each launcher has a method for:
* start simulation
* stop simulation
* launch constellation
* terminate constellation
* monitor constellation
The proper function is called based on the constellation type (also called configuration)

The boto code has moved from common to the cloudsimd daemon
values.title: CloudSim refactor for VPC

summary.raw:
Going from a machine centric approach to a constellation based one. Each launcher has a method for:
* start simulation
* stop simulation
* launch constellation
* terminate constellation
* monitor constellation
The proper function is called based on the constellation type (also called configuration)

The boto code has moved from common to the cloudsimd daemon
summary.html:
Going from a machine centric approach to a constellation based one. Each launcher has a method for: start simulation stop simulation launch constellation terminate constellation * monitor constellation The proper function is called based on the constellation type (also called configuration)

The boto code has moved from common to the cloudsimd daemon

values.description:
Instead of listening for changes comming as messages of different types from the cloudsim server, the web page polls the state of teh constellation every second. Widgets listen to these updates and populate themselves from that data.
This pull request will have a brother, later
values.title: polling vs pushing

values.description:
* The traffic shaper (TS) class has been removed. Now it is part of cloudsim-client-tools.
* The TS widget sets the target latency into the router/simulator machine. The controller will check this value periodically.
* Package loss widget has been removed because it is not used.
* Some tests has been improved.
values.title: Traffic shaper moved to cloudsim-client-tools

summary.raw:
* The traffic shaper (TS) class has been removed. Now it is part of cloudsim-client-tools.
* The TS widget sets the target latency into the router/simulator machine. The controller will check this value periodically.
* Package loss widget has been removed because it is not used.
* Some tests has been improved.
summary.html:
• The traffic shaper (TS) class has been removed. Now it is part of cloudsim-client-tools.
  • The TS widget sets the target latency into the router/simulator machine. The controller will check this value periodically.
  • Package loss widget has been removed because it is not used.
  • Some tests has been improved.

values.description:
I often use the python  console to import the cloudsimd module and:
* get the constellation data (list_constellations)
* delete the redis content (del_constellations)
I added methods to grab an AWS instance from name or instance id (if it did not get a Name yet)

Now with flexible ip assignment (for router)

summary.raw:

* get the constellation data (list_constellations)
* delete the redis content (del_constellations)
I added methods to grab an AWS instance from name or instance id (if it did not get a Name yet)

Now with flexible ip assignment (for router)
summary.html:
I often use the python console to import the cloudsimd module and: get the constellation data (list_constellations) delete the redis content (del_constellations) I added methods to grab an AWS instance from name or instance id (if it did not get a Name yet)

Now with flexible ip assignment (for router)

values.description:
The main problem was this line:

```
#!python

boto  = boto.pyami.config.Config(get_boto_path())

```
It should say:

```
#!python

boto.config  = boto.pyami.config.Config(get_boto_path())
```

The rest are minor tweaks. One test has been removed, cause the zip_cloudsim() is tested inside cloudsim_bootstrap()
values.title: CloudSim test fixed

summary.raw:
The main problem was this line:

```
#!python

boto  = boto.pyami.config.Config(get_boto_path())

```
It should say:

```
#!python

boto.config  = boto.pyami.config.Config(get_boto_path())
```

The rest are minor tweaks. One test has been removed, cause the zip_cloudsim() is tested inside cloudsim_bootstrap()
summary.html:
The main problem was this line:

boto  = boto.pyami.config.Config(get_boto_path())

It should say:

boto.config  = boto.pyami.config.Config(get_boto_path())

The rest are minor tweaks. One test has been removed, cause the zip_cloudsim() is tested inside cloudsim_bootstrap()

values.description:
This first initial installation performs the following actions:

* Install the pandora server in router trio machine. It needs mysql so it is installed also in router machine with a random root password.
* Install the pandora_console also in router trio machine. This is needed to get SQL schema and data and provides the web interface via apache2, which is being also installed in the router.
*  Install pandora agents in router, simulation and field machine.

Pandora console can be used from http://10.0.0.50/pandora_console/ with user admin and password pandora, as installed by default. You will need to wait until simulator and field machines are up to see the agents in your console.
values.title: Initial pandora installation in vrc_trio

summary.raw:
This first initial installation performs the following actions:

* Install the pandora server in router trio machine. It needs mysql so it is installed also in router machine with a random root password.
* Install the pandora_console also in router trio machine. This is needed to get SQL schema and data and provides the web interface via apache2, which is being also installed in the router.
*  Install pandora agents in router, simulation and field machine.

Pandora console can be used from http://10.0.0.50/pandora_console/ with user admin and password pandora, as installed by default. You will need to wait until simulator and field machines are up to see the agents in your console.
summary.html:
This first initial installation performs the following actions:

  • Install the pandora server in router trio machine. It needs mysql so it is installed also in router machine with a random root password.
  • Install the pandora_console also in router trio machine. This is needed to get SQL schema and data and provides the web interface via apache2, which is being also installed in the router.
  • Install pandora agents in router, simulation and field machine.

Pandora console can be used from http://10.0.0.50/pandora_console/ with user admin and password pandora, as installed by default. You will need to wait until simulator and field machines are up to see the agents in your console.

values.description:
Solves Issue#86:

Under the text field for adding a new user/admin's email address, add a small label that says "New User's Gmail Address" to be more clear that an email account is required, and not a name. One user started to enter the user's name, instead of the email address.
values.title: Add label to Add User field on Admin page

summary.raw:
Solves Issue#86:

Under the text field for adding a new user/admin's email address, add a small label that says "New User's Gmail Address" to be more clear that an email account is required, and not a name. One user started to enter the user's name, instead of the email address.
summary.html:
Solves Issue#86:

Under the text field for adding a new user/admin's email address, add a small label that says "New User's Gmail Address" to be more clear that an email account is required, and not a name. One user started to enter the user's name, instead of the email address.

values.description:
This program requires two YAML files (test files are included in yaml/ ). The first file contains a list of teams, with the team information (name, timezone, CloudSim constellation, ...). The second file contains a list of tasks with its information (title, latency, uplink, local times to start/stop the task, ...). For each team, this program performs the next operations:

  1. Create a sequence of tasks according to the YAML task file and team file.
  2. Convert the local start/stop times to UTC.
  3. Upload a JSON file containing the tasks into the Team's CloudSim.
  4. Load the set of tasks into the Redis DB running on the Team's CloudSim.

How can I test this tool using Amazon?

  1. Run CloudSim on your local machine.
  2. Connect to your local CloudSim and start two new CloudSim constellations (CS-01, CS-02).
  3. Connect to CS-01 and start a new simulator constellation (Sim-01).
  4. Connect to CS-02 and start a new simulator constellation (Sim-02).
  5. Each team should have a CloudSim and a simulator constellation associated. Update teams.yaml with the constellation IDs for each team.
  6. Run ./bin/send_tasks.py <teams_file> <tasks_file>
  7. A new task list should appear on each Team's CloudSim.
values.title: send_tasks.py : A command line tool for loading tasks into a list of constellations

How can I test this tool using Amazon?

  2. Connect to your local CloudSim and start two new CloudSim constellations (CS-01, CS-02).

values.description:
**Note: This pull request should be merged after [this one](#!/osrf/cloudsim/pull-request/39/send_taskspy-a-command-line-tool-for/diff). The only real difference is the file bin/attach_cloudsims.py** 

This tool updates the VRC Portal's database. For each team present in the teams.yaml file:

  1. The IP of its associated CloudSim is retrieved. 
  2. A new line containing teamID and CloudSim IP is appended into a temporary text file.
  3. The text file is upload into the VRC Portal.
  4. The VRC Portal database is updated using the text file.

**How can I test the code using Amazon?**

  1. Go to the vrcportal-test and log in as an admin. Check the Practice/Final tab of some Team's page and verify that the CloudSim URL is not available (there is a new box for this purpose). 
  2. Launch a CloudSim on your local machine.
  3. Connect to your local CloudSim and launch two new CloudSim constellations (CS-01, CS-02)
  4. Modify teams.yaml (you can find test files inside the yaml/ directory), by adding the new constellation names to two of the teams.
  5. Run the tool.
    Ex) ./bin/attach_cloudsim.py yaml/teams.yaml -p vrcportal-test.osrfoundation.org
  6. Go to the vrcportal-test and log in as an admin
  7. Go to the Team's page of the teams you modified and check the Practice/Final tabs. The URL of each CloudSim should be available.
  8. Follow the link and verify that a CloudSim is there.
values.title: attach_cloudsims.py : A command line tool for attaching a cloudsim to every team

  8. Follow the link and verify that a CloudSim is there.

values.description:
Operations involved sim_stop (stop task button, timeout, ... ?) should not just kill the simulator if we need the state.log to be complete. We can replace it by a command which check the simulator to be not paused again after gzlog pause.

Special care to launch gazebo or ros commands through ssh, it will need source setup.sh files before.
values.title: Make stop_sim function to wait for state.log to be complete

summary.raw:
Operations involved sim_stop (stop task button, timeout, ... ?) should not just kill the simulator if we need the state.log to be complete. We can replace it by a command which check the simulator to be not paused again after gzlog pause.

Special care to launch gazebo or ros commands through ssh, it will need source setup.sh files before.
summary.html:
Operations involved sim_stop (stop task button, timeout, ... ?) should not just kill the simulator if we need the state.log to be complete. We can replace it by a command which check the simulator to be not paused again after gzlog pause.

Special care to launch gazebo or ros commands through ssh, it will need source setup.sh files before.
